<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">Some speculations on the life and person of the</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">Reader.</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">We can suppose that the reading public was brought into</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">existence by two causesl when the playhouse was shut down in</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">       <!-- 1642 -->; and, less 
            <choice>
              <sic>definietly</sic>
              <corr>defintely</corr>
            </choice>, when the play outgrew the</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">theatre--when, that is, it could only be fully realised</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">if read. In the great age of Elizabethan literature</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">the reading public must have been<add hand="ms" place="above">was</add> a small one <add hand="ms" place="inline">,</add> <del hand="ms">and</del></l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">composed mainly of scholars and aristocrats. The lack of</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">general common reading is proven by the long pause,</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">between <rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-wsha" key="Shakespeare, William">
            <choice>
              <sic>Sahkespares</sic>
              <corr>Shakespeare's</corr>
            </choice></rs> death and the eighteenth century,</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">when the plays of 
            <choice>
              <sic>Shakepare</sic>
              <corr>Shakespeare</corr>
            </choice> hung suspended,</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">unrealised. They had to wait until the printed book was</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">held in many hands, read by many eyes <del hand="ms">in the private room</del></l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">before they received the other life, the detailed the</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">
            <choice>
              <sic>pa tciaulr</sic>
              <corr>particular</corr>
            </choice> life that the reader confers Again the small</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">ness of the reading public and its special quality accounts</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">for the scarcity of Elizabethan criticism, and the general</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">nature of what criticism there is. It is written by writers</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">for writers. Both <rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-psid" key="Sidney, Philip">
            <choice>
              <sic>Sindey</sic>
              <corr>Sidney</corr>
            </choice></rs> in his <rs type="literary-work" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#lit-defe" key="Defense of Poesie">defense of Poesie</rs></l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">and <rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-bjon">Jonson</rs> in <rs type="literary-work" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#lit-timb" key="Timber: Or, Discoveries">Discoveries</rs> are concerned with</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">the theory of writing; not with 
            <choice>
              <sic>partciular</sic>
              <corr>particular</corr>
            </choice> instances.</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">They are <add hand="ms" place="above">not</add> conscious of any curiosity on the art of the</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">general public. The reading public is not yet asking</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">for explanations, for instructions. The general public</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">never read the play. They had to draw in the play</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">as they sat or stood at 
            <choice>
              <sic>t e</sic>
              <corr>the</corr>
